qas.question: How did the British assure numerical superiority in taking Louisbourg?

answers.text: French reinforcements were blocked by British naval victory in the Battle of Cartagena

qas.question: Identify two other French possessions captured by the British.
Who did the British deport from Lie Saint-Jean?
What is Lie Saint-Jean called today?
How much were the French outnumbered at the Battle of Carillion?

context: British Prime Minister William Pitt's focus on the colonies for the 1758 campaign paid off with the taking of Louisbourg after <a0_0>French reinforcements were blocked by British naval victory in the Battle of Cartagena<a0_0/> and in the successful capture of <a1_0>Fort Duquesne and Fort Frontenac<a1_0/>. The British also continued the process of deporting <a2_0>the Acadian population<a2_0/> with a wave of major operations against <a3_0>Île Saint-Jean (present-day Prince Edward Island)<a3_0/>, the St. John River valley, and the Petitcodiac River valley. The celebration of these successes was dampened by their embarrassing defeat in the Battle of Carillon (Ticonderoga), in which <a4_0>4,000 French troops repulsed 16,000 British<a4_0/>.
